newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Sleepy Russian MinFins ease on client selling.
newsitem.headline: Sleepy Russian MinFins ease on client selling.

text.p: Russian MinFin bond prices eased in quiet trade in the absence of investor interest before year-end and on low-scale client sales, dealers said on Wednesday.
"Nothing happened today except the fourth and fifth tranches have gone down on client selling. The market is otherwise difficult to move," an ICFI Moscow Partners Bank dealer said.
Moscow Business World Bank dealer Sergei Kovzharov said the main reason for the quiet decline was the current low investor interest in Eastern Europe and Russia, in particular.
"Dealers are closing positions when there is no interest. Besides, many are awaiting further negotiations with the International Monetary Fund and approval of the 1997 budget," he said.
The ICFI Moscow Partners Bank dealer said permanent support was seen on the market from abroad.
"They seem satisfied with yields, but no price jump is likely now. Client orders may even push down levels."
Dealers said prices of MinFin bonds, along with other emerging market debt, would track U.S. Treasuries on Thursday U.S. jobless claims data due at 1330 GMT.
